title: Few-shot Species Range Estimation with FS-SINR
author: Christian Lange (University of Edinburgh), Max Hamilton (UMass Amherst), Elijah Cole (GenBio AI), Alexander Shepard (iNaturalist), Samuel Heinrich (Cornell), Angela Zhu (University of Edinburgh), Subhransu Maji (University of Maryland), Grant Van Horn (...), Oisin Mac Aodha (University of Edinburgh)
relevance_why: This paper's focus on few-shot learning could inform similar approaches in audio and speech datasets where labeled samples are scarce. The methods implemented could inspire audio classification or restoration tasks by leveraging limited data.
background: Few-shot species range estimation aims to predict the spatial range of unnoticed species using only a few recorded locations, helping in ecological research.
contribution: This paper introduces the FS-SINR model to solve few-shot species range estimation, achieving state-of-the-art performance in predicting species distributions.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods mostly require large amounts of data for accurate predictions and rely on extensive retraining for new species.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work introduces a Transformer-based architecture that requires no retraining at inference and can process additional metadata to enhance predictions.

key_innovation: FS-SINR’s capability to instantly predict species range for previously unseen species using minimal data and additional metadata integration represents a significant advancement.
real_world_impact: By improving the ability to estimate species' ranges with limited data, this approach could enhance biodiversity conservation strategies and ecological studies.
limitations: The deterministic nature of outputs limits the exploration of diverse range maps from the same input context.

new_terms.FS-SINR: **Few-shot Species Range Estimation**; a model designed to predict the spatial distribution of species from minimal observational data.
new_terms.pseudo-absence: **Pseudo-absence** refers to location samples that are randomly selected to serve as negative examples in ecological modeling, where confirmed absence data is lacking.
